meanings.def: one of the round objects under a car, bicycle, bus, etc. that turns when it moves
examples: He braked suddenly, causing the front wheels to skid.
the rear wheels of the car
She was killed when she was crushed under the wheels of a bus.
I had lightweight wheels on my bike.
tractors with powered front wheels
on wheels One of the boys was pushing the other along in a little box on wheels.
A tyre blew and we had to change the wheel.
She braked too hard and the wheels locked.
She fell under the wheels of a bus.
The wheels were still going around.
the sound of wheels crunching over snow

meanings.def: the round object used for controlling the direction in which a car, etc. or ship moves
examples: Always keep both hands on the wheel.
behind the wheel Never get behind the wheel if you're too tired.
This is the first time I've sat behind the wheel since the accident.
at the wheel A car swept past with Laura at the wheel.
Do you want to take the wheel (= drive) now?
She fell asleep at the wheel and crashed into a tree.
I drove the first 200 miles and then Steve took the wheel.
I saw the car drive past, but didn't recognize the woman behind the wheel.
I spend a lot of time behind the wheel.
The bus set off again with a fresh driver at the wheel.
At last he had his own wheels.

meanings.def: a flat, round part in a machine
examples: gear wheels

meanings.def: an organization or a system that seems to work like a complicated machine that is difficult to understand
examples: the wheels of bureaucracy/commerce/government
It was Rob's idea. I merely set the wheels in motion (= started the process).

meanings.def: having the number or type of wheels mentioned
examples: a sixteen-wheeled lorry

meanings.def: a car, bicycle, etc. with the number of wheels mentioned
examples: a three-wheeler

meanings.def: not paying enough attention to what you need to do
examples: Let's hope the regulators are not asleep at the wheel.
They were asleep on the job as the financial crisis deepened.
Someone must have been asleep at the switch to alow this to happen.

meanings.def: a person who is a small part of a large organization
to help something to happen easily and without problems, especially in business or politics
to start working very hard at a particular task
examples: Everyone is going to have to put their shoulder to the wheel.

meanings.def: to prevent somebody from putting their plans into operation
to waste time creating something that already exists and works well
examples: There’s no point in us reinventing the wheel.

meanings.def: a situation that is difficult to understand because it involves complicated or secret processes and decisions
examples: There are wheels within wheels in this organization—you never really know what is going on.

idioms.def: not paying enough attention to what you need to do
examples: Let's hope the regulators are not asleep at the wheel.

Someone must have been asleep at the switch to alow this to happen.

idioms.def: a person who is a small part of a large organization
to help something to happen easily and without problems, especially in business or politics

idioms.idiom: put your shoulder to the wheel
idioms.def: to start working very hard at a particular task
examples: Everyone is going to have to put their shoulder to the wheel.

idioms.idiom: put a spoke in somebody’s wheel
idioms.def: to prevent somebody from putting their plans into operation
to waste time creating something that already exists and works well
examples: There’s no point in us reinventing the wheel.

idioms.def: a situation that is difficult to understand because it involves complicated or secret processes and decisions
examples: There are wheels within wheels in this organization—you never really know what is going on.

meanings.def: to push or pull something that has wheels
examples: She wheeled her bicycle across the road.

meanings.def: to move somebody/something that is in or on something that has wheels
examples: The nurse wheeled him along the corridor.

meanings.def: to move or fly in a circle
examples: Birds wheeled above us in the sky.

meanings.def: to turn quickly or suddenly and face the opposite direction; to make somebody/something do this
examples: (+ adv./prep.) She wheeled around and started running.
Jim wheeled back to face me.
wheel somebody/something (+ adv./prep.) He wheeled his horse back to the gate.
He wheeled his horse around.

meanings.def: to do a lot of complicated deals in business or politics, often in a dishonest way

idioms.def: to do a lot of complicated deals in business or politics, often in a dishonest way
